All game data has been deleted.

The Japanese language is special, because it uses three different writing systems: hiragana and katakana, two syllabaries (syllable alphabets) invented in the 9th century, and the Chinese characters (kanji) which were imported even earlier.\nThis app is intended to teach you hiragana: the system most learners start with, because it has the most widespread use.\nLetâ€™s get into it! Weâ€™ll start with the vocals. This is I, pronounced like â€˜eâ€™ in â€˜meâ€™. Click on the animation to hear how it sounds like!
Now try to draw it yourself! Use exactly two strokes: draw first the left part, then the right.
Good, weâ€™re off to a good start! (You can tap on your solution every time to hear how it is supposed to be pronounced.) Now do it again in the same manner, so you do not forget it in a minute.
Great! Letâ€™s continue. This is E. Sounds like the first â€˜eâ€™ in â€˜everyâ€™.
Draw it! Start from the top. Again, two strokes only.
As they say, repetition is the mother of learning. One more E, please.
And another one! But this time, there is no hint!
Nice! Back to I now. I hope you have not forgotten how it looks like yetâ€¦
Awesome! Now draw these two vocals back to back, I first, E second. You have four strokes.
Congratulations! Youâ€™ve learned a word ğŸ‰
Yes, you have seen exactly zero consonants yet, but in Japanese, words comprising only vocals are much more common than in English.\nThereâ€™s another one actually! Draw IIE. You have 6 strokes.
Surprise-surprise! IIE is also a word ğŸ‰
A new task. Are you afraid to continue? Answer in Japanese.

Itâ€™s good that youâ€™re fearless, because the next challenge is timed. You need to know how to draw characters fast!\nThe timer isnâ€™t running yet: it will turn on once you start drawing. You'll have 10 seconds.\nThe question is: are you afraid this time? Answer in Japanese.

You made it! Now... what if instead of ten seconds you had just five? Itâ€™s less than a second per stroke!\nThis is probably the toughest challenge youâ€™ve encountered so far. Will you fail it? Answer in Japanese.

People usually learn vocals first, but since you know how to say no now, letâ€™s make a quick detour to learn its counterpart. The Japanese for yes is HAI.\nThis word comprises two characters: one for HA and I, which you already know. There is no character just for H in Japanese: every consonant must be superseded by a vocal. There is one exception though... which weâ€™ll get to in due time.\nFirst things first, letâ€™s learn how to draw HA.
Now draw it yourself. Use three strokes.
And once again, without a hint. For good measure.
Okay, you are ready now. Do you wish to continue? Answer in Japanese and use exactly five strokes.
Uh-oh! The computer recognises your drawing as %1$s. Try again!
An animation showcasing how to draw the hiragana character %1$s
A hint reminding how the hiragana character %1$s looks like
Congratulations, you have beaten every challenge Iâ€™ve got! The game is completed, but you can return to the main menu and revisit every character and word you have learned!
Timothy G. Stout, â€˜Japanese Hiragana & Katakana For Beginners: First Steps To Masteringâ€™, Tuttle, 2011
